Dialogue.Stage Direction: On Earth, in a rural part of the London Borough of Barnet, a genuine policeman is using a genuine blue police box to telephone the station. His words are muffled by the nearby traffic noises. He has propped his bicycle up against the box and is just dropping his rubbish in a nearby bin when the police box whibbles, and his connection is interrupted. It sounds as if a Tardis has just materialised in the police box. As the policeman tries to re- establish communications, the door opens and he is dragged inside. There is the sound of evil laughter.
The Doctor is pacing amongst the ivy-clad pillars of this inner part of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Chameleon circuit.
What? Doctor.
Look, whenever you see me in this part of the Tardis, pacing up and down like this, be a good chap and don't interrupt me, will you, unless it's terribly urgent. It's not terribly urgent, is it?
Well, no.
Good, so now you'll know in fact there's no need for you to come barging in here at all, but if it is terribly urgent you can always ring the Cloister Bell.
The Cloister Bell?
Yes.
What's that?
Well, it's a sort of communications device reserved for wild catastrophes and sudden calls to man the battle stations.
But the Tardis doesn't have battle stations.
No, no, no, nothing along those lines. I sometimes think I should be running a tighter ship.
A tighter ship?
Yes. The second law of thermodynamics is taking its toll on the old thing. Entropy increases.
Entropy increases?
Yes, daily. The more you put things together, the more they keep falling apart, and that's the essence of the second law of thermodynamics and I never heard a truer word spoken. Come on. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They sit on a small stone bench.

Dialogue.Line: Have you seen the state of the time column recently? Wheezing like a grampus.
But it will get us to Gallifrey, won't it?
Gallifrey? Oh yes, yes. Are you really set on going to Gallifrey?
Yes.
Oh.
That is where we're going, isn't it?
That's one of the questions I was just pondering. There's bound to be an awful lot of fuss about Romana. Why she stayed in E-space, official investigations, that sort of thing.
The Time Lords won't approve?

What? She has broken the cardinal rule of Gallifrey. She has become involved, and in a pretty permanent sort of way. I think that you and I should let a few oceans flow under a few bridges before we head back home.
So we don't get to go to Gallifrey.
Yes. Let me put another question to you. I have a place in mind that's on the way, well, more or less, give or take a parsec or two. It's my home from home. It's called Earth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A young Australian woman in purple air stewardess uniform comes out of a house on Ursula Street, then remembers something. Her aunt is waiting for her in a tiny soft-top convertible car. Everyone say Hi to  Janet Fielding.

Dialogue.Line: Passport.
Oh, she's going to go back in there. Forget her head if it wasn't screwed on, I tell you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The little car refuses to start. Tegan comes back out of the house again and gets into the car.

Dialogue.Line: There we go.
Okay, Aunty Vanessa, let's go. More choke. Easy on the throttle as you turn her over.
While I do that, dear, I wonder if you'd mind shutting the front door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door to number 43 is standing ajar.

Dialogue.Line: And don't forget your bag. You might need it.
Rats. I promise I'll get organised one day.
Now calm now, Tegan, dear. Look, we've got plenty of time. You get yourself so excited.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan runs back to the house as a plane passes overhead.

Dialogue.Line: Wish you and I had half her energy, though.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan returns with her bag, after finally remembering to close the door.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry, Aunty. First flight nerves, I guess. Here, let me have a go.
That's a good idea. I'm not having any luck here with it at all this morning. It's really very cold.
It's cold.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan takes over the driver's seat.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. Got all your things? Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan turns the key and the engine starts first time.

Dialogue.Line: I've got the knack.
You sure have.
Ladies and gentlemen. Although the fasten seatbelt sign is now off, we suggest that you keep your seatbelt fastened when seated. If necessary, you may move about the cabin. Smoking is now permitted.
Earth's the planet with all the oceans, isn't it?
That's the chap.
Wet.
Britain is. That's the one place where we can find these blue boxes.
Tardises?

Yes, but they're not. No spacious accommodation, no viewer screens. They don't even time travel. Just elementary Earth communications devices, and more or less obsolete by the time we'll be arriving there. There's some in the North that are still in use.
But we've got communications devices.
But not a police box.
A police box?
Yes. What the mathematical model of a Tardis exterior is based upon.
I'd like to see Earth, but why go all that way just to look at something that looks like the Tardis?
Because I want to measure it.
Whatever for?
Block transfer computation.
I've never heard of that.
I'm not surprised. Logopolis is a quiet little planet.
Logopolis? But I thought we were going to Earth?
No, that's the other place. We go to Logopolis afterwards.
You mean we're going to measure Logopolis, too?
No, no, no. It's all to do with the chameleon circuit problem. We measure the police box on Earth, then we take the measurements afterwards to Logopolis. Come on, I'll show you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bell begins to toll.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
The Cloister Bell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The brave little car has got a flat tyre. Tegan pulls into the lay-by with the blue police box.

Dialogue.Line: It's stopped.
Yes.
Well, what does it mean?
Well, nothing, when it's not ringing.
But it did ring. Is there a wild catastrophe?
Apparently not.
Well, something must have made it ring.
Yes, or else our old friend entropy's nibbling away at the system circuitry. Let's take a look.
But you were saying about the chameleon circuit.
Hell's teeth, Aunty Vanessa. It is a flat.
I thought there was something funny about that steering, but you wouldn't listen to me.
Well, it's only the exterior of a Tardis that exists as a real space- time event.
But mapped on to one of the interior continua.
Precisely. That's very good.
So you can change it into anything you like.

Ah, well, that's a sore point. According to the handbook, yeah, because the outer plasmic shell of a Tardis is driven by the chameleon circuit, or so the theory runs. In practice I always meant to ask Romana to help me fix it one day.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He opens the door to her room and they look in.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. I suppose we're going to miss Romana.
And K9, too.
Yes. Still, the future lies this way.
Come on, Aunty. We've got to do something.
Yeah. Telephone for help.
Absolutely not. Cars. I hate 'em.
That's not what you said when I offered you a lift.
Sorry, Aunty, but you just don't get this sort of silly aggravation with aircraft.
Well, perhaps if we sit here and look helpless, someone might offer us a lift.
Pathetic. We'll crack this ourselves. Now then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan looks in the boot.

Dialogue.Line: Where's the wheel spanner?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Adric finally get back to the console room.

Dialogue.Line: So the chameleon circuit's stuck?
Exactly.
In Totter's Yard.
In a totter's yard. Anyway, it was ages ago. It doesn't matter. She was in on Gallifrey for repair when I borrowed her.
I thought she was yours?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets underneath the console.

Dialogue.Line: Well, on a sort of finders-keepers basis, yes. I should have waited till they'd done the chameleon conversion, but there were other pressing reasons at the time. Anything happening up there?
No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A panel pops open and a control board comes out.

Dialogue.Line: Yes.
Good. Ah.
What do these numbers and letters mean?
Well, it's an early version. The instructions have to be punched in by machine code.
Oh, how boring.
Boring? In theory we should be able to do things like this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits a few keys and the scanner draws an outline of a pyramid.

Dialogue.Line: There. You have a door there.
Yes, I suppose that's useful.
Well, we've got to be able to get in and out.
No, no, I mean being able to change like that.
That's how the Master hid from us on Traken. Anyway, if this worked, I'd just have to punch a few buttons like this, and we'd be a pyramid.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner diagram becomes the familiar police box in space.

Dialogue.Line: It's very distinctive.
Yes. I'm not sure we should be distinctive.
Why? Who's looking for us now? You've disposed of the Master.
Yes. But since we left Traken, and then the Cloister Bell.
Wild catastrophe?
Mmm.
Man the battle stations?
Yes. Ah, Earth. Nearly there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vanessa is reading from the car's handbook while Tegan does the manual labour.

Dialogue.Line: Completely remove the wheel-nuts, remove the hub trim, exchange the road wheels and replace the hub trim and wheel-nuts. Oh, dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan is still struggling with one wheel nut when she looks up to see an aeroplane passing overhead.

Dialogue.Line: Now that's what I call travelling.
You and your aeroplanes. I sometimes think you should have been born with wings.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clang!

Dialogue.Line: Oh, rabbits.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises unnoticed on the lay-by, near the real police box.

Dialogue.Line: By the way, dear, don't you think you should put a jack underneath there before you take that wheel off?
We've missed.
What's supposed to happen?
At least, I suppose it's a miss, but I thought just for once we'd materialise on the right coordinates.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner shows the edge of the real police box and the two women struggling with the car wheel.

Dialogue.Line: Two point six metres off target. What a landing.
It's not bad for the Tardis.
That's what I just said. What a landing. No, no, no, no. Don't open the door.
Aren't we going out there to measure it?
There's no need to draw attention to ourselves. There's a simpler way, if I can just organise it. The Tardis and I are getting rather better at these short hops.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The policeman's bicycle falls over as the Tardis materialises around the police box.

Dialogue.Line: It's just like the Tardis!
I hope not. That could produce some unpleasant dimensional anomalies. No, it's just an ordinary police box, around which we've materialised with considerable finesse, I hope you've noticed.
Police telephone, free for use of
No, no, no, leave it alone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts the telephone back on it's cradle.

Dialogue.Line: It's a communications device. Adric, take down these dimensions. I've been meaning to do this for centuries.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan gets the spare wheel from the boot.

Dialogue.Line: It's nearly done.
I don't really belong at ground level, Aunt Vanessa.
Yeah.
I didn't mean to be rude about your car. It's very nice of you to give me a lift to the airport.
My little runabout's used to being insulted by now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Across the road, a white figure watches from behind the fence.

Dialogue.Line: Cars are all right, I guess. Just more fun to have your own plane back home. What kind of a maintenance schedule are you running here, Aunty Vanessa? This tyre's flat, too.
Three point six seven metres normal to the back surface.
How much more of this is there?
It has to be measured in every dimension.
But it can't have thirty seven dimensions! You said it was an ordinary Earth object.
In every dimension. I need every detail. The Logopolitans convert that into a precise mathematical model.
Why?
Well, to overlay it on the Tardis.
And that's block transfer computation.
Well, it's a way of modelling space-time events through pure calculation.
Really?
No, transcendentally. It's quite hard to explain in a word.
Creating solid objects through pure mathematics.
Yes. I meant to do it all of course when they first offered to do the chameleon conversion for me. It's highly specialised. But they say it'll work. Leg up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mysterious Watcher sees Vanessa trying to pump up the flat spare tyre.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, please, dear, do let's get a man from the garage.
No way. The stories I've heard about the way they exploit helpless women. You want the job done well, you do it yourself, that's what Dad used to say.
Perhaps some knight errant will stop for us.
You have to learn to fend for yourself in the outback, you know.
Your father's farm is hardly the outback, my dear, and neither is this. You know, I can see a garage not even a quarter of a mile away.
Industry and application, Aunt Vanessa. Air stewardesses are supposed to be resourceful.
You're not an air stewardess yes, dear.
I will be after today.
If ever we get to the airport.
We will, just as soon as I get this wheel off.
Oh, god. You know, I thought I saw a man hovering over there. Perhaps he needed a wave of encouragement.
It's the 1980s, Aunt Vanessa. No knight errants.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric is on his stomach on top of the police box.

Dialogue.Line: So why do we have to go to Logopolis if the theory's as simple as you say?
Because the actual working-out's incredibly tedious. Lots of fiddly computations. Much better to leave it to the Logopolitans. They do it standing on their heads.
Not with a computer?
Standing on their heads is an expression.
Oh.
As a matter of fact, they don't use computers, they use word of mouth.
Is that another expression?
No.
They speak it?
Mutter. Intone.
Intone the computations?
Yes.
Why?
I've wondered that myself. I never quite had the nerve to ask them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An unexpected noise comes from the console. The Doctor rushes over to it, and Adric joins him.

Dialogue.Line: Another instrumentation failure.
A gravity bubble?
No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits the console and it starts beeping.

Dialogue.Line: Definitely a gravity bubble. Pretty local too, by the look of it.
Is that dangerous?
Well, we'd better not dematerialise till I've investigated. I have a feeling I'm overlooking the obvious again. Back in two shakes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor stands in the Tardis doorway and looks at Vanessa and Tegan arguing over the flat tyres. He is about to go back inside when he sees the white figure across the road. Their eyes meet, then he goes back inside. Adric is trying to pick the lock of the police box.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing, Adric?
I thought it might have something to do with the gravity bubble.
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The police box door creaks open invitingly.

Dialogue.Line: I'm afraid you're right. No! You'd better leave this to me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters the police box and finds himself in a more dimly lit console room. Adric has of course followed him.

Dialogue.Line: Get back to the Tardis.
But this is the Tardis.
A Tardis, perhaps.
It looks just like yours.
Yes, down to the last detail. No, wait, wait.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The second police box still has the telephone dangling on its wire.

Dialogue.Line: This could be terribly dangerous. You'd better stay with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vanessa has got the old flat tyre off its hub at last.

Dialogue.Line: There you are, Tegan, dear. I've got the knack too.
I wish there was a knack to blowing up a spare tyre with a hole in it. Really, Aunt Vanessa, what's the point in driving around with a dud spare tyre?
It's the garage, then.
Crooks and swindlers, but I suppose we've got no choice.
Unless we wait for a knight errant?
No, thank you. Look, you stay here and get your breath back, and I'll go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan sets off, rolling the flat tyre.

Dialogue.Line: Take your bag, dear. You might have to pay for it. Ah, there's a girl. Good girl.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan stops at the police box and lets the tyre fall into a puddle.

Dialogue.Line: (reads) Police telephone, free for use of public. Advice and assistance obtainable immediately. Officers and cars respond to urgent calls. Pull to open.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Instead, the door swings open.

Dialogue.Line: That's funny. It's very peculiar indeed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan enters as the 'police box' dematerialises from the console room and we discover that Adric had used a set of library steps to get up on top of it. The doors close behind Tegan, trapping her.

Dialogue.Line: So it is another Tardis.
It's too early to tell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts the telephone back on its cradle.

Dialogue.Line: There are other things that can cause this sort of dimensional anomaly. See if you can do that again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric unlocks the police box.

Dialogue.Line: Hello? Anybody there?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She walks round the console.

Dialogue.Line: Well, there must be intelligent life at the end of this lot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She flicks a switch as if it is an intercom.

Dialogue.Line: Hello? Anybody receiving me? Hello? Come in, anybody. My name's Tegan Jovanka. I'd like to speak to the pilot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Cloister Bell tolls. She follows the sound to the interior door and opens it.

Dialogue.Line: Is that the crew in there?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan goes deeper into the Tardis.
Vanessa spots the wheel lying in the puddle, and the police box door ajar. She looks inside.

Dialogue.Line: Tegan? Goodness me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: This console room is even darker. Again, the telephone is dangling on its wire.

Dialogue.Line: How many more of these are there?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor replaces the receiver on its cradle.

Dialogue.Line: It couldn't be an infinite regression, could it?
I hope not, because if it is, we'll never get out of it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes Adric's badge for mathematical excellence.

Dialogue.Line: Here, you do it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric uses the pin to pick the police box door. A bell tolls.

Dialogue.Line: Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vanessa backs out of the police box, away from someone who is laughing evilly.

Dialogue.Line: No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She picks up the wheel to try and defend herself.

Dialogue.Line: Someone's trying to get in touch with us.
We can't go back now.
Done it.
We must be getting near to the nucleus of the bubble.
What's causing it?
Another Tardis.
What? Materialising round the police box just as we planned to do?
Yes. Someone's been here before us. Stay here, Adric.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters the police box.
And exits on the far side of the police box. Plain clothes and uniformed police have arrived to investigate the abandoned little car.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, good morning.
Good morning. This your vehicle?
Which vehicle?
The sports car.
No.
Ah.
I just wondered how you came to be here. There is only the road, after all.
It isn't easy to explain.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric comes out of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Now just a minute, officer. You don't realise what's going on here.
No, sir, and I don't want to have to go into detail. You want to think yourself lucky that I don't have to be the judge.
Me lucky? You don't think that I? You do think.
I'm not paid to have opinions, sir. I'm paid to do my duty.

Well, I do have opinions. This is the calling card of the most evil genius in the universe and I have to tell you gentlemen, I've got to get after him. Now, if you'll just help me to create a diversion, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric looks around for something to use to create the diversion.

Dialogue.Line: I think you'd just better come along to the station with us, sir.
I'd love to.
Just to assist us in our enquiries.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric picks up the policeman's bicycle as the policemen escort the Doctor to their patrol car.

Dialogue.Line: Would you mind awfully if I stopped to telephone my solicitor?
You can do that back at the station.
It seems we're going to be awfully busy at this station of yours. I mean, isn't that a telephone box?
That's a police box, sir, not for
But that would do fine, don't you agree?
Look, sir, if you want a formal arrest
Er, no.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets into the back of the patrol car with the detective. Adric is lying on the ground apparently having fallen from the bicycle in the road.

Dialogue.Line: Help! Help me, please! Quickly! Help! Please help!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone gets out of the car.

Dialogue.Line: Help!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs for the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Get him, Davis!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The policeman runs to help Adric.

Dialogue.Line: Help!
Not that one, you fool! The other one!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Doctor get into the Tardis, Adric gets up and pushes the bicycle into the policeman then follows the Doctor inside.
The Cloister Bell is tolling and the police box has disappeared.

Dialogue.Line: The box has gone.
It could be anywhere in the Tardis.
Battle stations?
Absolutely.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The detective taps politely on the Tardis door.

Dialogue.Line: Come on now, sir.
The Cloister Bell!
A choice of emergencies. We'd better dematerialise first.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the sound is very slow.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter?
The Tardis is very sluggish. We may not have any choice at all.
Get the key.
It's dragging us back. We'll have to find some more power from somewhere.
The Cloister Bell!
Well, shut the door, then. There must be some way of simplifying this. Architectural configuration, that's the one.
What's that?
Interior allocation of space. Adric, I'm going to jettison Romana's room.
Are you sure?
This is life. Nothing's sure.
I'm sorry, I just
Look, do you want a quick decision or a debate?
Sorry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The time rotor starts moving.

Dialogue.Line: You see? There's no need to shout.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the lay-by, a policeman hands a set of keys to the detective.

Dialogue.Line: We're moving.
Yes.
So that other Tardis really has gone.
Somehow I rather doubt that. Come on, Adric.
But aren't you going to answer the Cloister Bell?
Why don't you answer it? Go on. Go on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric leaves. The Doctor flicks some switches and listens closely to the console. The Cloister Bell stops, and Adric runs back.
The detective opens the door to an ordinary police box, containing a clipboard on the wall and some hazard lights.

Dialogue.Line: There's got to me some trick to this, Davis.
This place is unreal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She sits on a stone bench, then a police box materialises in front of her.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, it stopped.
Yes, so now we know.
Know what?
The message was very faint. It was from Traken.
Traken? How's Nyssa?
Nyssa's all right.
Tremas?
Vanished. The Master must have had a second Tardis hidden away somewhere.
The Master's escaped from Traken? But why take Nyssa's father?
To renew himself. He was very near the end of his twelfth regeneration.
He's taken over Tremas?
Yes.
Can a Time Lord do that?

Well, not just a Time Lord by himself, but with some of the powers of the Keepership still lingering. Huh, and I was so sure. I was so sure. He must have known I was going to fix the chameleon circuit.
He read your mind?
Well, he's a Time Lord! In many ways, we have the same mind.
Are we still going to Logopolis?
No, how can we with the Master in the Tardis? They're a retiring people. They like a quiet life. There's no telling what a creature like that would do on Logopolis.
So how do we flush him out?
And there's no saying what that might do to the Tardis systems. Can you swim?
Yes.
Good. Materialise the Tardis underwater and open the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Down in the Cloister Room, Tegan walks round the police box. The door opens invitingly. The Doctor calls up an aerial view of London on the scanner.

Dialogue.Line: That's the River Thames. We'll put down there.
And water sluices in and floods out the whole Tardis.
Yes. Adric, shut down everything. Fold back the Omega configuration.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric gets on the floor underneath the console.

Dialogue.Line: Folded back.
Good. Exponential cross-field?
Halted.
Good. Pathways to conditional states seven to seventeen?
Closed.
Excellent. Main and auxiliary drive?
Ended.
Good. Now, we're partially materialised, so there'll be a slight jolt. Are you ready?
If you are.
What? Well, I'd feel more confident if you just said yes.
Yes.
Good. Here we go, then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan gets jolted.

Dialogue.Line: This is too much!
A gentle splash-down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Thud! They fall to the floor.

Dialogue.Line: We must have touched bottom.
Touched bottom?
Yes. Good thing the water was there to break our fall.
Crazy idiot of a pilot! Wait till I have a word with him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laughter comes from the open door of the police box.

Dialogue.Line: Who's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is standing braced across the doors.

Dialogue.Line: Careful, now. The water pressure could send us both flying. Ready?
Yes.
Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric presses a button and runs to join the Doctor. The doors do not move.

Dialogue.Line: That's odd. There's no pressure on those doors at all.
Perhaps we aren't down very deep.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The doors swing open and they step outside.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. I thought there's be a perfectly simple explanation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis has parked herself neatly on Cadogan Pier in Chelsea, jutting out into the Thames. In the Cloister room, Tegan is backing away from the evil laughter.

Dialogue.Line: Nearly got it right.
Nearly, but not quite right. There's something not quite right about all of this.
The Master.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They look up at the Albert Bridge, where a pale figure is watching them. It gestures to them to come up.

Dialogue.Line: Nothing like this has ever happened before. I've got to get to the bottom of this. You stay here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan escapes from the Cloister Room. Adric watches as the Doctor talks to the Watcher up on the bridge.

Dialogue.Line: I definitely came in this way. So this must be the way out.
Round and round like a hamster in a cage! Somebody must be in charge here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan finally burst into tears, and the police box dematerialises.

Dialogue.Line: We'll just have to give it one more go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She runs out, and a fig tree in a pot materialises.

Dialogue.Line: Door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric presses the button to close the outer doors.

Dialogue.Line: Who was that? Doctor, who was that?
Set.
Where are we going?
Logopolis.
What?
I've just dipped into the future. We must be prepared for the worst.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises from the Pier.

Dialogue.Line: So that was the Master?
Hmm? How do you deduce that?
I just guessed.
Never guess. Unless you have to. There's enough uncertainty in the universe as it is.
But I can help you. Well, can't I?
In the ordinary way, yes. This is something far too serious.
What sort of something?
A chain of circumstances that fragments the law that holds the universe together.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises in mid-air over a sinuous arrangement of adobe houses dominated by a large radio telescope.

Dialogue.Line: Logopolis?
Yes. That aerial's a recent addition.
Are we going to be staying long?
You are.
What?
You and I have to part company.
Look, if you're going after Nyssa, I'm coming too.
Adric, don't argue.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan runs in.

Dialogue.Line: I demand to see whoever's in charge of this ship!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Elegant silver-haired Logopolitans wearing gold and black drapery gather at an open area on the edge of town. The Tardis materialises.

Dialogue.Line: Tegan Jovanka. And I'm not answering any more questions until you tell me exactly who you are.
I'm Adric. That's the Doctor.
Who is she? Where did she come from? What are we going to do with her?
You can take me right back where you found me, Doctor whoever you are. My aunt's waiting in the car to take me to the airport.
Your aunt? Woman in the white hat, red sports car?
You've seen her?
Well, a little of her. That settles it. She's got to come with us.
Settles what? Now wait a minute, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The fig tree in a pot leaves the Cloister Room and appears behind the Logopolitans just before the Doctor pokes his head out of the Tardis door.

Dialogue.Line: My dear Doctor. Logopolis is honoured by your visit.
Well, it's very nice of you to put it like that, Monitor.
I demand to know what's
Shush. We're all very honoured to be here.
(sotto) Where's here?
Logopolis.
Welcome. Time has changed little for either of us, Doctor. You continue to roam the universe, while we persist in our simple existence on this planet.
Yes. The antenna's new, Monitor.
Occasionally our researches require what is sometimes called technology. But for the most part, our computations are enough.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and the Monitor walk along a passageway where people sit in doorways working abacuses.

Dialogue.Line: If your computations can help solve a problem in my Tardis, I'd be eternally grateful, Monitor.
You have recorded the dimensions we need as data?
Yes, all noted down. Monitor, I don't wish to press you but my problem is now extremely urgent.
It will only take a moment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They arrive at a large red door.

Dialogue.Line: Why don't we proceed to business immediately?
Yes, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A few computer terminals with some plastic wrapping still on them, and a large printer are in the room.

Dialogue.Line: But all this is new, Monitor, and vaguely familiar.
This is purely for our advanced researches.
I thought you said they didn't use computers.
That's right.
May I have the dimensions?
Yes, historically the Logopolitans do everything
The dimensions, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Outside, the fig tree turns into a stone column and dematerialises. The Monitor glances at the figures in the notebook.

Dialogue.Line: This will only take a moment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Monitor sits at a console, closes his eyes and starts chanting.

Dialogue.Line: Keree gorok gorok, keree gorok per denesta zel octa zarel gorok gorok keree
(sotto) What's he doing?
The numbers. He's recreating the Tardis.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The chant echoes along the adobe streets. Abacuses clatter and people mutter.

Dialogue.Line: The code is being compiled.
Thank you, Monitor. I'm certainly looking forward to having a properly functioning Tardis.
You mean those people we saw in the streets are working it out for themselves?
Yes.
What, without technology?
Block transfer computation is a complex discipline, way beyond the capabilities of simple machines. It requires all the subtleties of the living mind. Is that not so, Doctor?
Oh, indeed, Monitor, indeed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Out in the town, the column has appeared behind one man sitting in his doorway, working. There is a whirring sound, a pot breaks and someone laughs over a tiny figure of the man now lying by his overturned stool.

Dialogue.Line: When am I going to get an explanation for all this?
Do you really feel up to an explanation?
I'll try.
Well. Adric, you explain.
It's not the Doctor's fault you wandered aboard.
Wandered? Listen, that ship was deliberately disguised as a police box. I just want to know who you are and where I am.
Look, I'd better explain.
This will restore your chameleon circuit, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes the piece of paper.

Dialogue.Line: Splendid, Monitor. I've really been looking forward to this. Of course! The Pharos Project! But this is a near replica of the Pharos computer room.
It is a perfectly logical copy.
What?
I always thought you underestimated the possibilities of block transfer computation, Doctor. You see, structure is the essence of matter, and the essence of structure is mathematics.
What, you can model the Pharos Project mathematically?
Of course, and supply the necessary raw energy.
Well, then, you can model any space-time event in the universe.
That is true. Now, shall we implement the solution to your little problem, Doctor?
Yes. Yes.
What's a Pharos, Doctor?
Ancient Greek for lighthouse.
What's a lighthouse?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The shrinking stops at about 2 1/2 feet.

Dialogue.Line: It's your codes that are doing this.
This is unheard of.
Well, how do we get him out of this?
A fault in the computation?
There must be something you can do to put him right.
Take the machine to the Central Register.
What are you going to do with it?
The Central Register, quickly. There may still be time. The honour of Logopolis is at stake.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Four Logopolitans carry the Tardis away.

Dialogue.Line: Must dematerialise. Dematerialise. Nothing working. Nothing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner shows the view from the Tardis as it is carried through the little streets.

Dialogue.Line: Will he be all right, Monitor?
If we can trace the error in time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They walk straight past the laughing Master sitting in a doorway.

Dialogue.Line: At last, Doctor. At last I've cut you down to size.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Inside the Tardis the Doctor can see the faces of the young people but cannot hear their voices.

Dialogue.Line: Hold on, Doctor. The Monitor is going to help you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Monitor is doing his number chant again.

Dialogue.Line: What's he doing?
The fault is in the dimensioning routine. We can trace it, if there's time.
Can I help?
Perhaps you can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go over to the printer and the Monitor tears off the paper.

Dialogue.Line: This is the machine code of the section that contains the error. I must check the external registers. Read it to me as we go. It is a copy of an Earth machine, so I'm afraid we have to make do with their clumsy symbols.
The Doctor taught me to read Earth numbering.
Where are you off to? There's work to be done.
We're doing it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Monitor and Adric go into a room with two rows of Logopolitans sitting with their abacuses, facing the walls. The Monitor goes along the row, looking over the worker's shoulders.

Dialogue.Line: A zero. Zero A. Four A. Nine two. Two C.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And into another identical room.

Dialogue.Line: A zero. Three zero.
I'm sorry, I thought we had found something. It's somewhere in the subroutine. Somewhere.
Monitor, I still don't see why you need all these people. Why can't it all be done on machinery?
For many uses machinery is unsurpassed, but Logopolis is not interested in such uses. Block transfer computation cannot be done with computers.
Why not?
Our manipulation of numbers directly changes the physical world. There is no other mathematics like ours.
You mean the computations themselves would affect a computer?
Of course. Change its nature, cause it to malfunction. Only the living brain is immune.
But you had a computer out there. You were using it.

To record the code, yes. To prepare new algorithms, yes. But we must not use it to run our programme. Now, we had reached zero four, zero seven, A zero, three zero, three eight. There are no errors in the registers. We must search the streets.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two screens are brought up to either side of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Sonic projectors.
What are they for?
They must be creating a temporary zone of stasis around the Tardis, but I don't really understand their science.
That goes double for me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Monitor is inspecting the home workers.

Dialogue.Line: Fourth block begins. A three. F eight.
E eight.
Sorry. E eight.
It is difficult, I know, but accuracy is of a vital importance.
Three three.
You can tell they're exploited.
These people are scientists.
So?
I've seen that look of dedication on my father's face.
Well, it doesn't seem to be doing any good, does it.
At least the dimensions are stabilised.
Eight nine. Nine A. E seven.
E nine.
Sorry. E nine. Two three. Wait! Wait. Did you say E nine? Look, it says E seven there.
You're right. And the next three numbers are wrong. This way.
The Tardis isn't much use to anybody that size, stable or not.
It gives us time.
Time to do what? We don't even know if he's alive in there.
They've arrested the dimension spiral. Things are looking up.
This is the street. The error should be somewhere here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They find a tiny Logopolitan lying on his stool. Then a second and a third.

Dialogue.Line: Sabotage.
Murder.
Interfering with the working of Logopolis. The most dangerous crime in the universe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has got his piece of paper.

Dialogue.Line: An error in the dimension subroutine. Somewhere here. I will not be beaten. I simply will not be beaten. But I could certainly do with a little more help from outside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric sees the Watcher standing at the end of the street.

Dialogue.Line: We must return to the Central Register, quickly.
The Monitor's done it. He's found the error.
The Doctor must reprogram block four of the dimensioning routine.
Those numbers are the ones that have to be changed.
If I show this to him, will he know what to do?
Yes.
Leave it to me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan holds the printout up to the light on top of the Tardis. Adric leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Adric?
The Master's out here somewhere.
I came here to find the Master.
No.
I must know what's happened to my father.
This could be very dangerous.
I'm coming with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan watches them walk off down the street, then returns to the Tardis.
The Doctor has got a couple of circuit boards out.

Dialogue.Line: The cheeseboard is the world, and the pieces the phenomena of the universe, as my old friend Huxley used to say. Cheese board? Chess board. And the opponent makes no allowances for mistakes nor makes the smallest concession to ignorance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: That's Thomas H Huxley's essay published in 1868, if you want to look it up.

Dialogue.Line: I'm an ignorant old Doctor, and I've made a mistake. There's only one direction help can come from now. I'll just have to sit here and wait.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Finally he looks up and sees the code on the scanner.

Dialogue.Line: Ah yes! Something along those lines.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric shows Nyssa the miniaturised people.

Dialogue.Line: The mark of the Master.
He must have added his own voice to the numbers and corrupted the Doctor's code.
And he's still here, somewhere. I saw him. He's been following us.
The Master?
I think so.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Watcher walks past behind them. Adric turns.

Dialogue.Line: Come on.
I hope he's seen it.
I'm sure he has. And with those figures, he will be able to restore the Tardis. It won't take long.
Well, while he's sorting that out, perhaps you wouldn't mind explaining something to me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She opens the door to the rows of Logopolitans at their abacuses.

Dialogue.Line: Back home in Brisbane, we call that a sweatshop.
This street.
Nyssa. Nyssa. Nyssa.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa turns back to find the voice.

Dialogue.Line: Nyssa, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She finds the right doorway.

Dialogue.Line: Father.
They don't smile, they don't talk to anybody.
Their language is the language of numbers. And they have no need to smile.
No need to smile?
We are a people driven not by individual need but by mathematical necessity. The language of the numbers is as much as we need. Now, it is important that we do not disturb them.
But if they don't talk to each other. You've done it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis is growing.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, there does seem to be some positive development.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tremas the Master has led Nyssa to the edge of town.

Dialogue.Line: But what is this mission of yours, father? You're so changed by it. You look younger, but so cold.
Logopolis is a cold place. A cold, high place overlooking the universe. It holds a single great secret, Nyssa, which you and I must discover together.
And the Doctor. The Doctor can help us.
Oh yes, the Doctor can certainly help us. You must return to him.
Father, I don't want to be parted from you.
No need to, my dear. Here, wear this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master fastens a chunky gold bracelet studded with big gems around Nyssa's wrist. It hurts her.

Dialogue.Line: It will keep us in mind of one another. Remember to tell no one that you've seen me, yet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor staggers out of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Monitor?
My dear Doctor.
I can't thank you enough.
There is no need.
You too, Tegan. You too. Where are the others?
Adric and Nyssa went to look for the Master.
What? They should know better than that. There've been enough unnecessary deaths as it is.
What deaths?
The murder of innocent Logopolitans.
And the murder of innocent Earth people.
Earth people?
Yes.
Aunty Vanessa?
Yes. I'm so sorry, Tegan. I'm so sorry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan moves away to cry.

Dialogue.Line: The Master's already at work on Logopolis. I'm going to stop him if it's the last thing I do.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At a street junction.

Dialogue.Line: Nyssa!
Did you find him?
No. We'd better go back to the Doctor.
Ow!
Where did you get that?
It's too small for me.
What is it?
It's a present. I've been trying to get it off.
Who from?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric touches the bracelet and gets an electric shock.

Dialogue.Line: I hope you haven't broken it.
Nyssa?
Adric, Nyssa. Come on. ADRIC + NYSSA: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the Registry, the sonic screens are wheeled out between the rows of Logopolitans. One of them gets up and follows, chuckling. It is the Master. When they get into the second room, he miniaturises the two men pushing the screens, and carries on with one of them to the end of the room. There he turns it round and plugs in a control unit then switches on.

Dialogue.Line: I don't want you two chasing after the Master independently. You, Adric, should know how dangerous he is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Watcher is waiting at the end of the street.

Dialogue.Line: That's the man who brought me from Traken.
Yes.
He said he was a friend of yours.
But he's the man on the bridge.
Yes.
You said to be prepared for the worst.
Indeed I did, and I am prepared for the worst.
Why are you prepared for the worst, Doctor?
Because he's here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: With all the calculations in the Registry halted by the stasis field, the Master removes his Logopolitan robe and wheels one of the screens in. The Monitor and Tegan turn round to see him.

Dialogue.Line: Please remain where you are. I have it in my power to bring Logopolis to a complete halt.
There's much more to this block transfer computation than we thought.
Yes, that's how they built a replica of the Pharos Project.
Yes. Yes, but why? Why build a replica of the Pharos Project? Central Register.
Listen.
I don't
Shush.
(sotto) I can't hear anything.
Quite.
Logopolis has stopped.
And I was vain enough to think it was me he was after. Logopolis is his target.
Turn that machine off. You have no idea what you're doing.
Merely emitting a sound-cancelling wave, Monitor. Logopolis is now temporarily suspended. The silence gives us an opportunity to discuss its future.
There will be no future. You are eroding structure, generating entropy.
An absurd assertion. I know the power of this device down to the last decibel.
But you do not know Logopolis!
But I shall, shan't I, when you've told me of the secret work you're doing here.
I cannot tell you.
Why have you created a copy of the Pharos Project? Hmm. The time has come for you to share your secret with me.
No! No one must know. That has been our firm decision.
Very well, we'll wait until you change it. Patience is a particular virtue of mine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Nyssa and Adric enter.

Dialogue.Line: Father!
That's not your father. Tremas is dead, murdered by him, the Master.
Nyssa.
You killed my father?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master takes Nyssa to one side.

Dialogue.Line: But his body remains useful. Without it I could not have conquered Logopolis.
This is not conquest, it's devastation.
It's nothing more than a blanket of silence.
Which is killing the Logopolitans and turning them to dust.
You expect me to believe that?
Yes!
You're destroying everything. It may already be too late.
You exaggerate, Monitor. Logopolis is not the universe.
But it is! Logopolis is the keystone. If you destroy Logopolis, you unravel the whole causal nexus.
Causal nexus? You insult my intelligence.
You're interfering with the law of cause and effect.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric grabs the sonic screen and moves it away from the main console. The Master presses a button on a box he is holding and Nyssa moves forward to grab Adric by the throat.

Dialogue.Line: Nyssa! Nyssa, let go.
That is a demonstration of the causal nexus.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan attacks the Master.

Dialogue.Line: You revolting man!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master throws her off. Nyssa is impassively choking Adric.

Dialogue.Line: The electro-muscular constrictor gives me complete control over that hand. Please replace the screen.
I wouldn't take orders from you if you were the last man in the universe.
Very well, one of your young friends will eliminate the other.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sends Tegan to obey. The Master releases Adric.

Dialogue.Line: Don't you understand? Logopolis is crucial to the whole of creation. This could mean the end of the universe.
I've never been persuaded by hyperbole, Doctor.
Then come into the streets and see what's happening.
No need for that. I can demonstrate the continued functioning of Logopolis from here. This device only creates temporary silence and can be switched off.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He does so. Silence remains. They all dash outside.

Dialogue.Line: You will hear nothing. Local disruption of structure is now irreversible. Logopolis is dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor shrugs off the Master's attempt to put his arm around his shoulders.

Dialogue.Line: Monitor? He's gone.
You do realise he's no chance of survival without our help?
The Monitor wouldn't abandon us.
He's trying to salvage the research team's work. He must have gone to the Central Register, yes?
Yes, maybe. It was the last addition to Logopolis. It might be the last one to survive. We need his knowledge. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: After the Master and the Doctor have left, Tegan and Adric come out of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: We all want to help the Doctor, but we've got to do as he says.
Listen. The Doctor's my ticket back to London Airport, so I'm going after him.
Tegan!
Have a nice trip.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric goes back into the Tardis, and it dematerialises. Meanwhile, the Doctor and the Master continue to avoid collapsing buildings.

Dialogue.Line: The rot is spilling outwards into the universe from this point after eons of constraint. Come on. Let's collect the Monitor and get out.
In my Tardis?
There's no other way.
You're assuming a lot, aren't you, Doctor?
Yes, aren't I.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Monitor is working at the main computer console.

Dialogue.Line: Monitor?
Logopolitan maths on a computer?
Monitor, the stability of
This is the programme we were developing to take the burden from our own shoulders. A series of data statements to keep the Charged Vacuum Emboitments open of their own accord.
What, do you mean the advanced research project?
The computer holds a complete log of the research.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master goes to the printer.

Dialogue.Line: Then the answer's here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He switches it on.

Dialogue.Line: Take care. The research is far from complete.
Monitor, were you on the right track? You must tell us about the project in every detail.
There is nothing to tell. It's all there for you to read. Now, I must get on with my work.
Doctor! Doctor!
I've done what I can, with the Registry in ruins. We must now realign the aerial, beam the programme out to space. There is a CVE close by we might still be able to re-open.
Doctor!
Yes.
Doctor.
Tegan, I told you to get out of here.
No thanks, Doctor. I'm staying with you. You're the only insurance policy I've got.
As safe as houses, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Registry ceiling starts to fall in.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, we must form a plan. I propose one, we withdraw to a position of temporary security. Two, we reconfigure our two Tardises into time cone inverters. Three, we create a stable safe zone by applying temporal inversion isometry to as much of space-time as we can isolate.
Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Monitor fades away before their eyes.

Dialogue.Line: Horrible.
Hardly more horrible than shrinking people.
No. Do what you like, Doctor. Logopolis is yours.
Doctor, stop him. He's getting away.
No, no, no, no, listen. Reconfigure the two Tardises into time cone inverters? It would work. What a brilliant mind.
And what a waste of two more brilliant minds if we don't do something soon.
The Monitor's programme. You can help me.
I can?
Yes. I want this in pieces.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They start to dismantle the computer console. The Master returns to his stone column Tardis inside an adobe house, and gets hit by a roof fall. The Doctor holds a bundle of circuit boards in his hands.

Dialogue.Line: As I thought.
What?
Bubble memory.
Bubble memory.
Yes. You realise what this means?
No, as a matter of fact I don't, Doctor.
Bubble memory is non-volatile. Remove the power and the bit patterns are still retained in tiny magnetic domains in these chips. The research team's final project is still here.
Which would be great if we had a computer to run it on.
I've an idea where we could find one. On Earth.
Earth.
Earth?
Yes. The Master's Tardis. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric and Nyssa watch the Watcher work the controls from the interior door.

Dialogue.Line: He's unsetting the coordinates. He's disconnecting the entire coordinate subsystem. But he can't do that. No!
What's the matter?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric shuts the door and drops to his knees.

Dialogue.Line: Down!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everything goes negative.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening?
We're being taken right out of time and space.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master is pinned by fallen debris.

Dialogue.Line: One good lift deserves another, don't you think?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master groans, and the Doctor heaves the large chunk of masonry of him.

Dialogue.Line: I'm very grateful.
Earth, please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everything comes back to normal. Adric peeks into the console room then shuts the door again.

Dialogue.Line: We're hovering.
Outside space and time.
But the Tardis isn't supposed to do that.
We seem to be safe.
Safe. Yes. The Doctor told the Watcher to look after us.
I'd rather be with the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the radio telescope's control room, the duty scientist is conducting music he is listening to on his headphones. He leaves the room just before the Master's Tardis materialises and the Doctor steps out, followed by the Master.

Dialogue.Line: The Pharos computer room.
Yes. I envy you your Tardis, Master.
Excellent, Doctor. Envy is the beginning of all true greatness.
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He looks through the door to see the technician getting himself a drink from a vending machine. They hide behind the Tardis as he comes back. Once the man has settled back in his chair, the Master points a device at him. The Doctor snatches it away.

Dialogue.Line: No!
It's the lightspeed overdrive, Doctor. You'll need that to accelerate the signal from the transmitter.
I'm so sorry. I thought you meant to shoot him.
Oh, Doctor. You can explain.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor walks behind the oblivious technician who is still enjoying his music.

Dialogue.Line: Ahem. Good morning. Good evening.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then the Doctor notices the Master has the real weapon in his hand and drags the technician's chair aside. Tegan comes out of the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: He's unconscious.
Never mind. I feel we've been spared a very difficult conversation.
When all this began, the Doctor wanted to reconfigure the Tardis so it'd work like the Master's.
What's wrong with it?
It's getting old.
Entropy again. You can't get away from it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Watcher beckons to them.

Dialogue.Line: He wants to talk to us.
To you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan takes to the technician's pulse while the Doctor fits the circuit boards to the computer.

Dialogue.Line: What makes you think this programme of the Monitor's is going to work, Doctor?
Oh, I don't know. It's a sort of vague faith in the nature of things, I suppose.
It's in the very nature of things for entropy to win.
Yes, well, it's the age-old battle, isn't it? Entropy versus structure. Still, while there's life there's six of one and half a dozen of the other.
Woolly thinking, Doctor.
Yes, but very comforting when worn next to the skin.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric finishes his conversation with the Watcher and returns to Nyssa.

Dialogue.Line: Well, what did he want? What did he say to you?
It's as if he knows what's going to happen.
But what did he say to you, Adric?
Come on, we've got work to do.
But where are we going?

The Pharos Project on Earth. Now, I've got to set the exact coordinates. Earth is in sector eighty twenty three of the third quadrant. The temporal settings are laid in on this panel. It always looks so easy when the Doctor does it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Nyssa flicks the scanner switches. It shows a heavily condensed cluster of galaxies.

Dialogue.Line: Adric, the scanner. Adric.
The whole universe. Of course. We're beyond space and time.
That must be the entropy field. Where's the Earth?
I can't see it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner zooms in on Sol and it's planetary system. Saturn is very clear.

Dialogue.Line: It's there.
Earth's galaxy has a few more hours left.
Adric, I can't see Traken.
Traken should be
I can't even see Metulla Orionsis. The Master killed my stepmother, and then my father, and now the world that I grew up in, blotted out forever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan looks out of a window then goes back down the corridor to the control room.

Dialogue.Line: The dawn's coming up. There are security guards outside.
Any good?
It's still not running. The programme's useless. It's time to abandon this line of reasoning.
Of course. The programme's not being fed into the core.
Well?
We start again.
Right, hold on. We're going back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everything goes negative.

Dialogue.Line: Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises in some bushes below a giant radio telescope. Jodrell Bank, probably, even though they are really at Crowsley Park BBC receiver station with the big wire antennae stretched across fields.

Dialogue.Line: Just like Logopolis.
The Earth people use it to beam messages to the stars. The Doctor calls it reiterated invitation to alien intelligences in deep space.
And that's us.
So they'll be very pleased to see us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric and Nyssa leave the Tardis, and hide from a security patrol.

Dialogue.Line: It's running.
If you call this alien gibberish a programme.
Well, we'll just have to wait until the data reaches the CVE.
First we must reach the transmitter and connect up the light speed overdrive.
Yes.
What about the guards?
I suggest we use your Tardis.
Impossible. The light speed overdrive's disconnected.
We've still got to get across to the antenna control room.
I agree.
I agree too, for what it's worth.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Adric and Nyssa make their way through scrub. Out in the corridor, the Doctor looks through a window to see the Watcher standing in the Tardis doorway.

Adric and Nyssa hide behind the hedge and watch the Doctor, Tegan and the Master who are behind a large tree stump. The Master aims his weapon at the patrol. The Doctor takes it off him and throws it away. This alerts a guard.

Dialogue.Line: Intruders! After them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The trio hide behind a shed as the guards meet up with another patrol. Adric and Nyssa are in the background.

Dialogue.Line: Sentimental fool. Thanks to you, we're now weaponless.
Nyssa and I have heard your message across the universe and have come to answer your call.
Message? What? Now who are you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tegan runs out.

Dialogue.Line: We are the alien beings who
Listen. Here, you fellows, you've got this all topsy turvy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and the Master sneak away. The Watcher goes back inside the Tardis. As the Doctor and Master run back to the telescope, the Master finds his weapon in the grass. The Doctor reaches the telescope and goes up to the control room. The Master returns to the Pharos Project computer room and takes the technician's walkman then goes into his own Tardis, laughing.
The Doctor enters and looks at the mess of wires and circuit boards. One piece has a flashing red light. The Master laughs.

Dialogue.Line: From here, Charged Vacuum Emboitment is in line with the constellation Cassiopeia.
Three C four six one.
I decided to use my Tardis after all. Three C four six one. Three zero four four.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master taps in the coordinates, and the giant dish begins to move.

Dialogue.Line: You see, Doctor, I overlook nothing.
You overlooked the light speed overdrive.
I gave you this to demonstrate my trust.
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master throws the unit out of the door.

Dialogue.Line: What?
But I don't take foolish risks. The real light speed overdrive is here.
What? And powered up, I see.
We have only to connect this cable from the computer room and the job is done. The aerial's now aligned to the CVE. As you devised the plan, I think the honour should be yours, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master retreats to another door as the Doctor takes the two computer connectors and joins them together.
The Master goes out onto a walkway underneath the antenna, which is now pointing directly upwards, and speaks into the tape recorder.

Dialogue.Line: Peoples of the universe, please attend carefully. The message that follows is vital to the future of you all.
Well?
The data's reached the CVE. It's stabilising.
So it works. Congratulations, Doctor. I always knew you'd do it.
You did most of this.
Oh, no. I was little more than a humble assistant, but I have learned a great deal. And now I think it's time for you to go and explain the presence of your friends. There's quite a hubbub outside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dogs are barking below.

Dialogue.Line: You're quite right. One mistake now could ruin everything.
I know that, Doctor, and it could happen so easily.
What do you mean?
The universe is hanging on a thread. A single recursive pulse down that cable and the CVE would close forever. Even a humble assistant could do it.
You're mad!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master produces his weapon, then switches on the tape recorder to broadcast his message to the universe.

Dialogue.Line: Peoples of the universe, please attend carefully. The message that follows is vital to the future of you all. The choice for you all is simple. A continued existence under my guidance, or total annihilation. At the time of speaking, the
Blackmail.
No, Doctor, I'm merely reporting the state of affairs. I have it in my power now to save them or destroy them.
You're utterly mad.
Back, Doctor. The proceedings must not be interrupted. It's mine. The CVE. It's all mine.
Only while that cable holds.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves the control room. The Master notices and follows, only to trip over the scarf which has been tied across it. He drops his weapon. There is a struggle and it falls to the ground. Nyssa, Adric and Tegan watch in horror at events above them. The Master runs back into the control room and changes the coordinates of the antenna. The walkway begins to tilt as the antenna moves back from vertical to horizontal. The Master watches from the doorway as the Doctor tries to hang on. Meanwhile, guards climb the ladder to the control room. The Doctor crawls to the other end of the walkway and uses a wrench to try and stop the mechanism. He pulls out the cable, but falls, dangling from the end of it in mid-air. His enemies flash before his eyes.

Dialogue.Line: (rotting version) Predictable as ever, Doctor.
Doctor.
(Pirate Planet) Doctor.
Doctor.
Doctor.
Doctor.
Doctor.
Doctor, you shall die for this!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor makes it to a piece of antenna scaffolding, but cannot hold on. He falls to the ground. The Master goes into his Tardis, laughing, and it dematerialises just before the guards enter the control room.
Adric, Nyssa and Tegan run to the Doctor, followed by guards. He is staring up at the sky.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Doctor?
Doctor?
Doctor.
Doctor.
Doctor. K9: Doctor. ROMANA 1: Doctor. ROMANA 2: Doctor.
Doctor. Doctor!
It's the end. But the moment has been prepared for.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor points to a ghostly white figure, that walks forward.

Dialogue.Line: The Watcher.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Watcher merges with the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: He was the Doctor all the time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tom Baker turns into the Watcher, then gains youthful features and short straight hair. Peter Davison sits up.
